body: another simpler way might be simply keep your changes and start from a clean fork

noop, since jpg is already compressed. but packing multiple jpgs into a single binary file can improve read performance.

Travis run through earlier except for a lint problem that I consecutively fixed (https://travis-ci.org/dmlc/mxnet/builds/136388742) and had a seqfault on travis on the second run (https://travis-ci.org/dmlc/mxnet/builds/136410568).

No. @dickoa

For the first one, `Module` has intermediate-level APIs, you should just be able to call `forward` and `backward` by writing a simple data loop. For example, see [the loop](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/speech-demo/train_lstm_proj.py#L188).

For the second one, I guess a hacky way is just to get the underlying handle of NDArrays and make assignments accordingly. I guess as long as there are some global registry holding reference to all those NDArrays, the ref-counting GC should not deconstruct them.

I‘ve run cifar,The speed ratio is 3.Seem better speedup.
4gpus:Time cost=40.951
1gpus:Time cost=122.265
So gpu accelation can only be fit to conlution layers?

Could you help to give some advice why my mlp network can't speedup.How can I debug?
@tqchen

Usually it depends on communication cost(parameter size) vs computation.

If it takes more time to copy the parameters than computation, you cannot get speedup.  This is what happens in the mlp case

For speeding up data parallel code in MLP mechanisms like gradient compression will be needed, but not yet available in mxnet.
We can add an argument to allow context overriding, which might be cleaner solution than this one

So what u mean is that mxnet havn't supported pipeline between communication and computaion yet?
Can it possbile to support it in future?
BTW,how can I get the time about copy the parameters and computation?And commands?
I can't get it by nvprof command.
@tqchen

It support the overlapping of communication and computation. But the case
is when communication costs more than computation, it can slow things down

Since the changes are on a different fork the easiest is probably:

``` bash
git remote add oist https://github.com/oist/mxnet.git
git fetch oist
git checkout vc/deconv_compileerror
```

or you manually apply the changes.

@tqchen @piiswrong Please merge at your convenience
@tqchen plz merge this
You need to use `ipython notebook` or `jupyter notebook` to open these notebook files.

@tqchen Maybe there is also difference in the backward pass. If I were right, SoftmaxOutput never computes cross entropy, but use 1 for all training samples in the backward pass. I figure this behavior is intended, since the Softmax implemented as a python operator does the same. But, is this supported theoretically or by empirical experiments?
@WuZifeng It's the gradient of the cross-entropy loss used in classification problems. Refer to http://ufldl.stanford.edu/tutorial/supervised/SoftmaxRegression/

Because we use type A projection[1], which don't have learnable parameter, a following BatchNorm is unnecessary. Facebook's implementation confirms it [2].
I've also tried type B projection [1], which is performs better than type A projection with 1x1 kernel (see the code comments in #2046). In this case, a following BatchNorm helps.
For the kernel size issue, I've do some experiments using 2-GPU in #2327 and #2366. It shows that the batch size affect the accuracy greatly. Maybe a smaller batch size works with 1x1 kernel, but I didn't do comprehensive experiments about it.

[1] He, Kaiming, et al. "Deep Residual Learning for Image Recognition." arXiv preprint arXiv:1512.03385 (2015).
[2] https://github.com/gcr/torch-residual-networks/blob/master/residual-layers.lua

What usually works is to :
Use this tool : http://www.dependencywalker.com/
With the tool, select libmxnet.dll in the directory where mxnet is installed. (site-packages\mxnet-0.7.0-py3.4.egg\mxnet)

It almost always shows you dll's that it cannot find.
You need cudnn.
I haven't tried MxNet on Windows. It seems cuDNN is the cause. I recommend @juliandewit's solution.
@sxjscience Thanks very much! It was my fault. I thought the gradient were in a different form. Apologies for bothering you.
@bdlacree  does your input_shape is (100, 1, 50, 300) ?

@ryanphjohnson  I have successfully implemented the neural-style in Scala #1821 #2100 。
From my experience, if you what to transfer from one language to others, you need to figure out what actually the original code is doing. For me, it takes about a week to transfer python to scala by running the python code many times to figure what each function is doing.
I updated the list a bit.

Maybe you can find how to do that in the example of cnn-text-classification.
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/cnn_text_classification

@Ldpe2G Thanks for the tip! I was a bit concerned about following the python version too closely. I feared the interface with MXNet would be significantly different from language to language. Its comforting to know that you were able to take the python and in a week or so able to convert it to Scala. You give me hope!
I've also verified the compilation. @vchuravy Merge from master and rebase?

Hi @piiswrong @hjk41 

I found the GPU-based mxnet didn't work well on my laptop. I have the same problem about mxnet mentioned above. The performance was very good when using CPU-based mxnet, while the GPU-based method had a low accuracy around 10% on mnist dataset.

My OS is win 10 64-bits, and the device graphic is nividia GTX 960M,  CUDA 7.5. I used 20160531-win 10-baniry-release to install the mxnet on my laptop. In addition, I have tested the CUDA with C and pycuda, both of them were Ok. 

So, I would like ask how to deal with it? Any help could be appreciated. Thank you.
@CharlesMei Try the method here http://eli.thegreenplace.net/2014/02/19/squashing-github-pull-requests-into-a-single-commit . You can, for example, use `git rebase -i dmlc/master`
I have make everything works now (in both CPU and GPU). And I am working on write an example to prove rightness of CTC. Will submit code in next week.

I'm updating to provide some additional information:

If I restart R and fit a simple FF network, the predict() function usually works. When I try to fit a CNN, though, {mxnet} throws the error (above). 

After trying the CNN, I can't get predict() to work again, even with a simple FF network. 

I'm really confused by this, since I've definitely gotten some predictions out of the CNN, but all of a sudden it doesn't work, and I've tried for a couple hours now to get it to work, but no dice. Even after a fresh restart the CNN prediction throws the same error.

Any ideas?

For what it's worth, the way that I can get the predict() to work temporarily is to (re?)create the mx.ctx.internal.default.value object thus:

```
> mx.ctx.internal.default.value = list(device="cpu",device_id=0,device_typeid=1)
> mx.ctx.internal.default.value
$device
[1] "cpu"

$device_id
[1] 0

$device_typeid
[1] 1

> class(mx.ctx.internal.default.value) = "MXContext"

# now predict works...
> preds = predict(model,t(X))
```

Thanks, linmx0130. I've been using that example all along, but I just don't see where they initialize the embeddings. (They seem to initialize weights using `mx.init.Uniform(0.01)`. 

I was hoping to find out how to set the initial values for this one particular part of the model. (i.e., initialize the weights to the word2vec values). Do you know if that's possible?
The total data input shape is (50,300,1,30000), with batchsize 100. The model seems to work on training and test data, but I just want to be sure that the Flatten() is doing what it should.
already fixed in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/2385/files

@bdlacree  could you provide the dataiter code? I think your input shape may be wrong, 
you can run the following code to see what Flatten is doing:

import mxnet as mx
import numpy as np

x = mx.symbol.Variable('data')
shape = (2, 2, 3, 4)
data_tmp = np.ones(shape)
arr_data = mx.nd.array(data_tmp)
arr_grad = mx.nd.empty(shape)

test = mx.symbol.Flatten(data=x)
exe_test = test.bind(mx.cpu(), args=[arr_data], args_grad=[arr_grad])
exe_test.forward()
print exe_test.outputs[0].shape

The lookup tabel seems different to other part of the network. In the example the embeddings are used as the input of the network, but not a real part of the network. You can find more details in [data_helpers.py](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/cnn_text_classification/data_helpers.py). But if you want to set the initial values for other particualr part of the model, I think you'd better try to hack the initializer.

That's an optional memory saving stuff. I followed resnet starting with a 7x7 conv and 3x3 max pooling then 3 blocks of fractal unit. I can get the network trained without memonger, but the main issue I have here is the path-pruning dynamically. #1492 could be a choice, but I don't want to waste time on computing stuffs which are not used at all.
Same issue for Mac El Capitan 10.11.5
All these operators are fairly easily extended to multiple DTypes.
@celestesosmart @tlkahn Have you disabled tried to disable OpenMP in dmlc-core? See https://github.com/dmlc/dmlc-core/pull/135

Will changing the code to this `hidden = mx.sym.broadcast_mul(1.0 - mask, hidden) + mx.sym.broadcast_mul(mask, next_state.h)` help? Also the broadcasting OPs currently do not support some shape combinations, see https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/elementwise_binary_broadcast_op-inl.h#L27-L38 .
@sxjscience Nope. The error is `mxnet.base.MXNetError: InferShape Error in _plus2's rhs argument`

The shape is:

``` python
self.provide_data = [(source_data_name, (batch_size, self.default_bucket_key[0])),
                     (source_mask_name, (batch_size, self.default_bucket_key[0])),
                     (target_data_name, (batch_size, self.default_bucket_key[1])),
                     (target_mask_name, (batch_size, self.default_bucket_key[1]))] \
                    + source_init_states + target_init_states
self.provide_label = [(label_name, (self.batch_size, self.default_bucket_key[1]))]
```

where default_bucket_key[0] is seq length for source, [1] for target.
@magic282 It seems that `hidden` and `next_state.h` have different shapes.

To build from source, you can follow http://mxnet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/how_to/build.html#building-on-windows . Also, the following CMake command may help:

```
cmake -G "Visual Studio 12 2013 Win64" ^
-DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release ^
-DCMAKE_CONFIGURATION_TYPES="Release" ^
-DMKL_INCLUDE_DIR="C:\\Program Files (x86)\\IntelSWTools\\compilers_and_libraries_2016\\windows\\mkl\\include" ^
-DMKL_RT_LIBRARY="C:\\Program Files (x86)\\IntelSWTools\\compilers_and_libraries_2016\\windows\\mkl\\lib\\intel64\\mkl_rt.lib" ^
-DOpenCV_DIR="E:\ThirdParty\opencv-3.1\opencv\build\x64\vc12\lib" ^
-DCUDNN_INCLUDE="C:\\Program Files\\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\\CUDA\\v7.5\\include" ^
-DCUDNN_ROOT="C:\\Program Files\\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\\CUDA\\v7.5\\lib\\x64" ^
-DBLAS=MKL ..
```

@AlecWong MXNet supports arbitrary NDArray shapes for data/label. Documents of the module API and basic python API may be helpful. Refer to http://mxnet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/packages/python/module.html and https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/notebooks/simple_bind.ipynb
The input data shape here can be `(batch_size, M, N)` and the output data shape be `(bath_size, C)`.

I know, this is because this change assume that output number in last layer should be the same as label size. This is true for SoftmaxOutput, but is wrong for CTC layer.

in ctc layer, label size is always smaller than output number in last layer.
I make a tricky change in pull request https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/2326
the python execution API is asynchronous, you can only measure the time after it is copied to numpy array
yes, make sure everything starts in mxnet's array, then everything will happen concurrently
Thanks to @sxjscience This feature is fully implemented
@sxjscience I feel that we can now directly replace sum_axis-> sum , while maintaining compatiblity, right? Maybe it is a good idea to do that

You can use ignore label. Check softmax output, ignore label

@shi27feng, According to the error message, the problem is in linking blas libraries. Also, on OSX, directly setting the USE_OPENMP flag in config.mk will not disable OpenMP completely, you'd better apply the fix in https://github.com/dmlc/dmlc-core/pull/135

I downloaded your libmxnet-0612.dll and unpacked it, and put it into the original mxnet file instead of the previous libmxnet.dll. But aftering install it using python setup.py install, there are some mistakes when runing import mxnet. What is up ? Thank you

Hi @pablozhang,
Probably you don't have OpenCV 3.1 and/or cuDNN v4 dlls, my libmxnet.dll was dynamically linked to these libraries, as opposed to the official one. You can download them here:
http://pan.baidu.com/s/1bpbURXt

Thank you very much for the contribution. This is an important feature.
The first should be straight forward. Like the other cudnn ops
